content.description: This route starts by climbing to the upper left portion of the detached flake. HEre one departs onto the face for an immediate showdown with a desperate sloper. After this sustained thin climbing leads up and over a bulge on some wicked coral-ly crimp features. A second crux resides 10' above the bulge and has been done with a normally wet pocket to the left or straight up with desperately small holds and cryptic movement. This route can be a first pitch to the looming arete of Violator, as they share the same anchors. It can also be linked into Violator in a single pitch. Be wary as a 70m will barely get you down.
content.location: Begins straight up from the left side of the large flake.

content.description: This route hosts some of the sickest and most exposed arete climbing in the entire Midwest. P1, 80'. Climbs a dihedral system with a few challenging moves surmounting a bulge after the first 20'. The second pitch begins with some small crimps moving up to a delicate traverse left to the bottom of the arete. Climb up the dihedral for several feet then hand traverse a rail to massive holds on the arete itself. A good rest can be had on the rail once you're poised on the arete, make sure to look down and enjoy! Good grips follow the arete until a mantel over and onto the slab above at the last bolt.
content.location: This route follows a line of bolts heading up a dihedral on the right side of the large detached flake.

content.description: Nail a short boulder problem off the deck to a smooth grey section below a bulge. Get started o the crux with good underclings and sneaky feet to a dynamic move to make the lip of the bulge. Hold it together for another 30' of thin face climbing to the anchors.
content.location: Standing at the large detached flake at the end of the wall Queen Anne's will be the leftmost line of bolts.

content.description: A good moderate with sometimes cryptic climbing. The crux is the first 20' of the second pitch which uses some some holds and funky moves. P1 can also be linked to the anchors on the first pitch of Violator for the easiest way to access the sweet p2 arete.
content.location: This route starts slightly uphill and right of the large detached flake in the Cove. Also about 40' up the wall is a decent size cedar growing on a ledge, the route starts below and just to the right.

content.description: Begins with a boulder problem on a semi detached but solid flake system heading up and left to an obvious dihedral. Burly and strange climbing gets you to the top of the dihedral with a crux getting through a short roof and onto the face above.
content.location: Luchador marks the beginning of the final cirque of routes at Pirate's. After hiking the trail to end where the large flake leans against the wall the route will be 30' to climber's left below the obvious bulgy dihedral.

content.description: Probably the hardest thing in the state currently. Never been done and only a glimpse of the truly hard climbing on the river.  An even harder extension exists above the anchors.
content.location: In the middle of the bluff is a huge white streak, the approach trail goes right to it. On the right side is a grey streak, this is the route.

content.description: P1, ~90'. Climb the white flake to the top then venture up and left into the dark and sometimes dirty face. The anchors are on a ledge below a huge dihedral. P2, ~50'. Climb the massive dihedral with bomber gear and a few bolts.
content.protection: Bolts and a handful of cams for p2. Fixed anchors.
content.location: Look for the massive dihedral high on the face near the landmark white streak. The route begins below the large white flake system.

content.description: Climbs a near vertical slab with small holds. The entire first pitch is consistent with stacked boulder problems after the initial thirty feet of climbing. The second pitch has not been done but after the anchors busts through a steep roof and then into a wicked dihedral lined with pockets and sculpted crimps.
content.location: After walking past the massive white streak and the large roof to climbers right the trail enters a large patch of river cane. Just then Calypso will be on the light grey face to the right of a large water ridden corner.

content.description: Climbs a vertical face on small crimps and pockets up to a challenging smooth section with slopers and micro crimps. The second pitch has yet to be sent.
content.location: Continuing down the trail from the white streak, which after entering the river cane grove dips down and crosses a heavily eroded water drainage, Black Pearl is approximately 50 feet past this point and begins from the trail. The route is identifiable by an ancient rusty bolt at chest height.

content.description: Sunny shortly after noon. Encompasses the bluff beginning at the large white streak that makes up the most impressive section of the wall.
